messages.subject: Re: Hayashi Tsuba  (was Re: Jingo Tsuba)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: Sorry for the tardy reply; I ve been away. Your questions have probably all been answered, but here is my very inexpert opinion. A. This one is easy. In
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
Sorry for the tardy reply; I've been away. Your questions have probably
all been answered, but here is my very inexpert opinion.
A. This one is easy. In the east Asian scheme of things for those using
the Chinese zodiac, sixty is the full cycle of 12 times 5 and a very
important year. 61 is merely the first year thereafter, so the launching
of a new cycle. To achieve 60 is the occasion for a major birthday
party.
B. I don't know.
C. I would think that the edge would go to Hayashi.
D. As a rule of thumb, given the way you posed the question, the
unsigned would be much less valuable, and were there really two that
were, cet. par., "identical" it would be amazing for the unsigned to
have survived being "up graded." The distinguished collector RB
Caldwell, from Dallas, once said that if one did commission work for an
important man, e.g., a Daimyo, the convention was not to sign as such
would be disrespectful. I have only seen that in print from him and have
no other authority, but if true it might explain why some super pieces
are unsigned.
E. I would think that in the arts a man's high point would be in
mid-life, particularly if he is involved in much creativity. If it is
just a matter of doing the same thing over and over, perhaps the
richness of experience would lead to his skills not seeming to wane.
Just my 2 cents worth.
Arnold Frenzel

>>> "Matthew E. Hoyle" <matthewhoyle@...> 06/28/04 3:50 PM >>>
Dear Arnold and Jim,

I would like to thankyou both for answering my question on Jingo tsuba.
It
has been some time for me to reply because I am quite busy at work. I
just
hope you did not think I was being rude by not replying earlier.
Eitherway
sorry, and I will try and get a reply in sooner in future, since I
really
appreciate the help. Now to the questions:

While staying on the topic of Higo Tsuba, I have some queries about the
Hayashi School that was patronized by the Kato, and later the Hosokawa
clan.
I hope you can help. These tsuba seem to have a very 'gentlemanly'
appearence about them, which makes them to my mind very attractive
pieces.

One tsuba I saw described was signed by the second mainline master
Shigemitsu. The commentary said that he must have been over 61 years in
age
(since it was signed), as this had special significance in Japan, and in
Higo tsuba were only signed after this point in life.

A. What is the significance of turning 61 in Japan &

B. Why wait untill then to sign guards in Higo? Did other schools in
Higo do
this as well, like the Jingo for example? How about entirely different
schools outside Higo, did they do this as well or not (doubtful?)

C. Last question(s), since I (again!) have never handled or even seen a
mainline Hayashi guard in the flesh or come up for sale, can anyone give
me
an indication as to how this would compare value wise to say a mainline
Jingo Tsuba? Would this be similar since they are both Higo, or would it
be
comparable to say a mainline Akasaka piece? (I am assuming that the
pieces
are in excellent condition).

D. Very last question: If A and B are so important, and we know how
important it is to have signed works for reference, how does this
translate
value wise to say perhaps two identical pieces. One signed and one mumei
with all other things being equal. What difference are we talking value
wise
here, if any?

E. I promise this is my last question: If tsuba are signed only later in
life (in Higo) might this imply that they are better pieces since the
maker
was more skilled at that time. Would a later identical tsuba be worth
more
than an earlier one by the same man (supposing both were signed and
dated
for arguments sake)?
In modern art a discussion has been raging for years about De Koonings
work,
since it was found out that he had gone quiete senile later in life.
This
led to a revaluation of his works, the earlier ones being worth more,
since
no-one wanted a very expensive painting by someone who was for all
intensive
purposes as Mad as a Hatter. Karel Apples early works are worth more
than
his later ones as well, albeit for entirely different reasons.

Regards, Matthew

messages.subject: Hayashi Tsuba  (was Re: Jingo Tsuba)
messages.msgSnippet: ... Reaching 60 years of age is still cause for a celebration since you ve completed one cycle and are about to start on the second (which you re not likely to
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
Reaching 60 years of age is still cause for a celebration since
you've completed one cycle and are about to start on the second (which
you're not likely to see the end of). I've heard it described as
being reborn and starting a second childhood, or just as the start of
old age.
-------------
Jim -

Just make it there myself. Don't know about the
second childhood; more like just being a curmudgeonly
old fart :-)

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hayashi Tsuba  (was Re: Jingo Tsuba)
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, The old Chinese/Japanese system had 12 Junishi (the zodiac animals) and 10 Jikkan that were combined to make a calendar cycle of 60 years.  Reaching 60
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
The old Chinese/Japanese system had 12 Junishi (the zodiac animals) and 10 Jikkan that were combined to make a calendar cycle of 60 years. Reaching 60 years of age is still cause for a celebration since you've completed one cycle and are about to start on the second (which you're not likely to see the end of). I've heard it described as being reborn and starting a second childhood, or just as the start of old age. In theory it is the point at which one no longer has to deal with dreary adult responsibilities, but I don't know if that was ever really what happened. Maybe someone else can provide further insight, particularly on how it was viewed 300 or 400 years ago, but I think that when you're 61, you're at a new stage of life as a person and fittings artist and you gain certain prerogatives.

I haven't studied exactly which groups followed this practice. Generally when a guard is inscribed with the maker's age, it's from late in life. Not all signed or signed and dated guards were done after age 61, although perhaps that was the case in Higo. It'd be hard to prove the date of all signed but undated or "un-age inscribed" guards to be sure none were done before age 61.

Hayashi Matashichi is probably the most highly valued maker among the Higo groups, although the first Jingo and Hikozo aren't far behind. I don't think that there are any known signed examples from the first Jingo or Nishigaki Kanshiro. Some Matashichi guards have kinzogan mei, but these are probably added later. I have heard some speculation that some could have been done by Matashichi because of the fineness of the inlay, but I don't think that's widely accepted. None of the soft metal first Hikozo guards are signed, but I think there's one iron one with a signature.

Later generations of the various groups did start signing, but you'll have to hit the reference books for yourself there. I think that for people who did sign, if all else is equal a signed guard would be priced higher than an unsigned one. A middling signed guard probably wouldn't be priced higher than a very good mumei one by the same maker. An unsigned Hayashi Matashichi is going to be worth way more than signed later generation work. The quality of the later generations' work is generally not close to the founder's work within a given line. The Kamiyoshi family, which started later, are the stars of later Higo.

The question about at what age the best work was done is complicated and would be different with each individual (and would also depend upon how much work that individual was actually doing himself). Senility aside, I find de Kooning's late work to be pretty wimpy. Further, I was surprised years ago when I realized that all of his paintings that I though were really great were done between '56 and '60. That would be what... de Kooning's mid 50's? Guess he couldn't have signed them if he was working in Higo.
Jim



Dear Arnold and Jim,

I would like to thankyou both for answering my question on Jingo tsuba. It
has been some time for me to reply because I am quite busy at work. I just
hope you did not think I was being rude by not replying earlier. Eitherway
sorry, and I will try and get a reply in sooner in future, since I really
appreciate the help. Now to the questions:

While staying on the topic of Higo Tsuba, I have some queries about the
Hayashi School that was patronized by the Kato, and later the Hosokawa clan.
I hope you can help. These tsuba seem to have a very 'gentlemanly'
appearence about them, which makes them to my mind very attractive pieces.

One tsuba I saw described was signed by the second mainline master
Shigemitsu. The commentary said that he must have been over 61 years in age
(since it was signed), as this had special significance in Japan, and in
Higo tsuba were only signed after this point in life.

A. What is the significance of turning 61 in Japan &

B. Why wait untill then to sign guards in Higo? Did other schools in Higo do
this as well, like the Jingo for example? How about entirely different
schools outside Higo, did they do this as well or not (doubtful?)

C. Last question(s), since I (again!) have never handled or even seen a
mainline Hayashi guard in the flesh or come up for sale, can anyone give me
an indication as to how this would compare value wise to say a mainline
Jingo Tsuba? Would this be similar since they are both Higo, or would it be
comparable to say a mainline Akasaka piece? (I am assuming that the pieces
are in excellent condition).

D. Very last question: If A and B are so important, and we know how
important it is to have signed works for reference, how does this translate
value wise to say perhaps two identical pieces. One signed and one mumei
with all other things being equal. What difference are we talking value wise
here, if any?

E. I promise this is my last question: If tsuba are signed only later in
life (in Higo) might this imply that they are better pieces since the maker
was more skilled at that time. Would a later identical tsuba be worth more
than an earlier one by the same man (supposing both were signed and dated
for arguments sake)?
In modern art a discussion has been raging for years about De Koonings work,
since it was found out that he had gone quiete senile later in life. This
led to a revaluation of his works, the earlier ones being worth more, since
no-one wanted a very expensive painting by someone who was for all intensive
purposes as Mad as a Hatter. Karel Apples early works are worth more than
his later ones as well, albeit for entirely different reasons.

Regards, Matthew

Dear Arnold and Jim,

I would like to thankyou both for answering my question on Jingo tsuba. It
has been some time for me to reply because I am quite busy at work. I just
hope you did not think I was being rude by not replying earlier. Eitherway
sorry, and I will try and get a reply in sooner in future, since I really
appreciate the help. Now to the questions:

While staying on the topic of Higo Tsuba, I have some queries about the
Hayashi School that was patronized by the Kato, and later the Hosokawa clan.
I hope you can help. These tsuba seem to have a very 'gentlemanly'
appearence about them, which makes them to my mind very attractive pieces.

One tsuba I saw described was signed by the second mainline master
Shigemitsu. The commentary said that he must have been over 61 years in age
(since it was signed), as this had special significance in Japan, and in
Higo tsuba were only signed after this point in life.

A. What is the significance of turning 61 in Japan &

B. Why wait untill then to sign guards in Higo? Did other schools in Higo do
this as well, like the Jingo for example? How about entirely different
schools outside Higo, did they do this as well or not (doubtful?)

C. Last question(s), since I (again!) have never handled or even seen a
mainline Hayashi guard in the flesh or come up for sale, can anyone give me
an indication as to how this would compare value wise to say a mainline
Jingo Tsuba? Would this be similar since they are both Higo, or would it be
comparable to say a mainline Akasaka piece? (I am assuming that the pieces
are in excellent condition).

D. Very last question: If A and B are so important, and we know how
important it is to have signed works for reference, how does this translate
value wise to say perhaps two identical pieces. One signed and one mumei
with all other things being equal. What difference are we talking value wise
here, if any?

E. I promise this is my last question: If tsuba are signed only later in
life (in Higo) might this imply that they are better pieces since the maker
was more skilled at that time. Would a later identical tsuba be worth more
than an earlier one by the same man (supposing both were signed and dated
for arguments sake)?
In modern art a discussion has been raging for years about De Koonings work,
since it was found out that he had gone quiete senile later in life. This
led to a revaluation of his works, the earlier ones being worth more, since
no-one wanted a very expensive painting by someone who was for all intensive
purposes as Mad as a Hatter. Karel Apples early works are worth more than
his later ones as well, albeit for entirely different reasons.

Regards, Matthew

----- Original Message -----
From: "arnold frenzel" <afrenzel@...>
To: <token_kenkyu_kai@...>; <matthewhoyle@...>
Cc: <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>; <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, June 20, 2004 3:31 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Jingo Tsuba


> Hi:
> I will take a stab at your very interesting question, one of many that
> you seem to come up with. You have provided part of the answer yourself
> by saying "rare" though of course that begs the question, why rare?
> Jingo tsuba were made in Higo and the work of the first three
> generations is considered particularly fine, thereafter as in most lines
> following generations could not stop adding gold and silver effects,
> becoming too symmetric, adopting features from other groups, etc.
> Higo, being remote from Edo, tended to supply products in the kodogu
> area, as with swords, that were somewhat outside the mainstream and they
> tended to be somewhat aloof from fashion elsewhere and to maintain that
> difference longer than other groups. Their market was more the samurai
> and less the merchant than would be true for people supplying the market
> in Edo and Osaka. The first three developed naturalistic designs never
> seen before or since, and thereby reflected the wabi sabi aesthetic that
> was very influential, particularly with the more severe samurai in the
> early Edo period. Their designs are very three dimensional, tastefully
> accented with gold and silver. Their most complementary counterpart
> seems to be found in the work of the Kanayama which, while sukashi, have
> the same rustic, subtle and unpretentious character. People also wonder
> whey they tend to go for some serious money. Jingo tsuba are instantly
> recognizable and fit well with any severe koshirae.
> Just a stab.
> Arnold
>
> >>> matthewhoyle@... 06/19/04 7:49 PM >>>
> Can anyone explain why Jingo tsuba are so sought after? They always
> strike me as being a bit crude and not very interesting, often decorated
> with an eagle or other beast that looks, well, kind of retarded. Is
> there any specific reason why these pieces have the status they do?
> After spending hours looking at pictures of them, I still fail to see
> where the (artistic) merit is.
>
> I admit to not having handled any genuine examples personally (since
> they are pretty rare), so perhaps these tsuba convey something in the
> handling that they do not in the pix?
>
> Matt
>
